Fiction

THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.

THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
CHAINFIRE, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) The 10th volume of the ''Sword of Truth'' fantasy series.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
BY ORDER OF THE PRESIDENT, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer tries to thwart a terrorist plot to crash a stolen 727 into the Liberty Bell.
UNEXPECTED BLESSINGS, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Continuing the story of the Harte family and its financial empire, told through four generations of women.

NIGHT FALL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A husband and wife who work for an antiterrorism task force reopen the investigation into the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 over the Atlantic, off Long Island, in 1996.
BLACK WIND, by Clive Cussler and Dirk Cussler. (Putnam, $27.95.) Dirk Pitt and his children confront a villain who has acquired biotoxins from World War II.
ENTOMBED, by Linda Fairstein. (Scribner, $26.) Alexandra Cooper, a Manhattan assistant district attorney, searches for the Silk Stocking Rapist and probes a murder case involving Edgar Allan Poe.
A SALTY PIECE OF LAND, by Jimmy Buffett. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A cowboy's life is changed forever when a 101-year-old woman hires him to be a lighthouse keeper in the Bahamas.
AFTERBURN, by Zane. (Atria, $24.95.) A chiropractor becomes enamored of a beautiful woman who works at a bank in Washington.
*LONDON BRIDGES, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The F.B.I. agent Alex Cross contends with two deadly enemies: the supercriminal known as the Wolf and the assassin known as the Weasel.
I AM CHARLOTTE SIMMONS, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.95.) A very smart, very innocent freshman from the Blue Ridge Mountains is amazed by what she finds at a prestigious university.
LIFE EXPECTANCY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) A pastry chef must struggle all his life against a family of evil madmen.
THE CAT WHO WENT BANANAS, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam, $23.95.) Jim Qwilleran and his cats investigate the suspicious death of an actor.

List
Nonfiction
WITNESS, by Amber Frey. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A memoir by the California massage therapist who testified for the prosecution in the murder trial of Scott Peterson.
AMERICA (The BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin, David Javerbaum et al. (Warner, $24.95.) ''The Daily Show'' offers an illustrated parody of a civics textbook.
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $29.95.) A historical investigation, by the author of ''Guns, Germs, and Steel,'' into why some societies succeed while others fail.
HIS EXCELLENCY, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.95.) A biography of George Washington, by the author of ''Founding Brothers.''
EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks.
CHRONICLES: Volume One, by Bob Dylan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) Recollections and observations from the singer-songwriter.
WHEN WILL JESUS BRING THE PORK CHOPS? by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $23.95.) Another volume of observations and opinions from the comedian.
FAITHFUL, by Stewart O'Nan and Stephen King. (Scribner, $26.) Two novelists -- and Boston Red Sox fans -- chronicle the 2004 championship season.
CONFESSIONS OF AN ECONOMIC HIT MAN, by John Perkins. (Berrett-Koehler, $24.95.) A former employee of an international consulting firm denounces the American global empire and its ''corporatocracy.''
HOW TO TALK TO A LIBERAL (IF YOU MUST), by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $26.95.) The columnist's writings about what's wrong with liberals.
THE LAST SEASON, by Phil Jackson with Michael Arkush. (Penguin Press, $24.95.) The basketball coach recalls his final year with the Los Angeles Lakers.

A BROTHER'S JOURNEY, by Richard B. Pelzer. (Warner, $21.95.) The brother of Dave Pelzer, author of ''A Child Called 'It,' '' details the abuse he himself suffered at the hands of their alcoholic mother. (+)
WHAT'S THE MATTER WITH KANSAS? by Thomas Frank. (Metropolitan/Holt, $24.) An examination of how conservatives ''won the heart of America.''
IN FOCUS. (National Geographic Society, $30.) A collection of more than 250 of National Geographic magazine's ''greatest portraits.''
DO-GOODERS, by Mona Charen. (Sentinel, $25.95.) The syndicated columnist indicts liberals for failing ''to help those they set out to help.'' (+)
*A PAPER LIFE, by Tatum O'Neal. (HarperEntertainment, $24.95.) In this autobiography, the actress remembers her child stardom, her marriage to John McEnroe and her battles with drug addiction.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Jan. 8, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest

BURY THE CHAINS: Prophets and Rebels in the Fight to Free an Empire's Slaves, by Adam Hochschild. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.95.) How the struggle availed, especially when black Haitian armies beat white French and British ones.
THE INTIMATE WORLD OF ABRAHAM LINCOLN, by C. A. Tripp. (Free Press, $27.) The case that Lincoln was gay, plausibly presented.
102 MINUTES: The Untold Story of the Fight to Survive Inside the Twin Towers, by Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn. (Times Books/Holt, $26.) A skilled reconstruction by writers at The Times.
SIGHTSEEING: Stories, by Rattawut Lapcharoensap. (Grove, $19.95.) Articulate fiction about coming of age in Southeast Asia.
THE MAN IN THE FLYING LAWN CHAIR: And Other Excursions and Observations, by George Plimpton. (Random House, $24.95.) A posthumous volume on eccentrics, dreamers and the rest of us.
SEVEN TYPES OF AMBIGUITY, by Elliot Perlman. (Riverhead, $27.95.) An Australian novel so large in its concept of fiction's grasp on the world it takes seven narrators just to tell it.
PREP, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House, $21.95.) A scholarship girl at a nifty prep school is thrust into a world of privilege in this novel.
BLINK: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) What happens when our minds work offstage, solving problems by hunch and instinct.

THOUGH THE HEAVENS MAY FALL: The Landmark Trial That Led to the End of Human Slavery, by Steven M. Wise. (Da Capo, $25.) The 1772 London case that found slavery so offensive the laws of England would not enforce it.
THE SCARITH OF SCORNELLO: A Tale of Renaissance Forgery, by Ingrid D. Rowland. (University of Chicago, $22.50.) A pair of 17th-century Tuscan brats manufacture Etruscan artifacts.
BACK FROM THE LAND: How Young Americans Went to Nature in the 1970's, and Why They Came Back, by Eleanor Agnew. (Dee, $27.50.) The trail of Aquarius, by one of the travelers.
The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books
